misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the Scanner's nextInt method and the int data type will automatically accommodate any numeric input, such as decimals, by either truncating them or rounding them to fit a whole number format.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java Scanner is type-rigid; nextInt does not perform automatic narrowing or truncation of floating-point input into integers. Instead, it expects an exact integer literal and throws an InputMismatchException if it encounters a decimal point.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the computer is aware of the problem's contextual bounds (0-100) because they were mentioned in the instructions, and that the machine will naturally interpret values outside this range as invalid or categorized by the closest rule.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The notional machine has no access to the problem description or real-world domain knowledge. It only evaluates the literal boolean expressions provided, meaning it will incorrectly assign an 'A' grade to values far exceeding 100 and an 'F' to negative values without explicit range validation.
